# GRE Word List

## A

<ol>
<li id="Aberrant"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#aberrant"><b>Aberrant</b></a>: <em>Markedly different from an accepted norm.</em></li>
<li id="Aberration"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#aberration"><b>Aberration</b></a>: <em>A deviation from the normal or typical course, often of a negative nature.</em></li>
<li id="Abstain"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#abstain"><b>Abstain</b></a>: <em>To deliberately avoid doing something, especially something that is considered unhealthy or immoral.</em></li>
<li id="Abstruse"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#abstruse"><b>Abstruse</b></a>: <em>Difficult to understand; obscure.</em></li>
<li id="Adamant"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#adamant"><b>Adamant</b></a>: <em>Unyielding in attitude or opinion, especially in the face of adversity or persuasion.</em></li>
<li id="Admonish"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#admonish"><b>Admonish</b></a>: <em>To warn or reprimand someone firmly.</em></li>
<li id="Admonitory"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#admonitory"><b>Admonitory</b></a>: <em>Giving a warning or reprimand.</em></li>
<li id="Aesthete"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#aesthete"><b>Aesthete</b></a>: <em>A person who has a deep appreciation for art, beauty, or nature.</em></li>
<li id="Aesthetic"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#aesthetic"><b>Aesthetic</b></a>: <em>Relating to the appreciation of beauty or art.</em></li>
<li id="Aesthetic"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#aesthetic"><b>Aesthetic</b></a>: <em>Concerned with the nature of beauty or artistic taste.</em></li>
<li id="Amalgam"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#amalgam"><b>Amalgam</b></a>: <em>A mixture or combination of different elements.</em></li>
<li id="Ambiguous"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#ambiguous"><b>Ambiguous</b></a>: <em>Having more than one possible meaning; unclear or inexact.</em></li>
<li id="Ambivalent"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#ambivalent"><b>Ambivalent</b></a>: <em>Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.</em></li>
<li id="Ameliorate"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#ameliorate"><b>Ameliorate</b></a>: <em>To make something better or improve its condition.</em></li>
<li id="Amenable"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#amenable"><b>Amenable</b></a>: <em>Open and responsive to suggestion or advice; willing to be influenced.</em></li>
<li id="Amorphous"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#amorphous"><b>Amorphous</b></a>: <em>Lacking a clear or definite shape or structure.</em></li>
<li id="Anomalous"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#anomalous"><b>Anomalous</b></a>: <em>Deviating from the normal or expected.</em></li>
<li id="Anomaly"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#anomaly"><b>Anomaly</b></a>: <em>A deviation from what is standard, normal, or expected.</em></li>
<li id="Antipathy"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#antipathy"><b>Antipathy</b></a>: <em>A deep-seated feeling of dislike or aversion.</em></li>
<li id="Antithetical"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#antithetical"><b>Antithetical</b></a>: <em>Directly opposed or contrasted; mutually incompatible.</em></li>
<li id="Apathetic"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#apathetic"><b>Apathetic</b></a>: <em>Showing or feeling little or no emotion or interest.</em></li>
<li id="Apathy"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#apathy"><b>Apathy</b></a>: <em>Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.</em></li>
<li id="Apocryphal"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#apocryphal"><b>Apocryphal</b></a>: <em>Of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true.</em></li>
<li id="Appease"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#appease"><b>Appease</b></a>: <em>To calm, soothe, or bring peace to; to placate or satisfy.</em></li>
<li id="Arbitrary"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#arbitrary"><b>Arbitrary</b></a>: <em>Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.</em></li>
<li id="Arcane"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#arcane"><b>Arcane</b></a>: <em>Understood by few; mysterious or secret.</em></li>
<li id="Arduous"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#arduous"><b>Arduous</b></a>: <em>Involving a lot of effort and difficulty; strenuous.</em></li>
<li id="Artful"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#artful"><b>Artful</b></a>: <em>Skillful or clever, especially in a deceitful or cunning way.</em></li>
<li id="Artful"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#artful"><b>Artful</b></a>: <em>Having or showing creative skill; cunning or crafty.</em></li>
<li id="Ascetic"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#ascetic"><b>Ascetic</b></a>: <em>Practicing severe self-discipline and abstention from all forms of indulgence, typically for religious reasons.</em></li>
<li id="Ascetic"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#ascetic"><b>Ascetic</b></a>: <em>Characterized by self-denial and austere living.</em></li>
<li id="Askance"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#askance"><b>Askance</b></a>: <em>With suspicion, mistrust, or disapproval.</em></li>
<li id="Audacious"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#audacious"><b>Audacious</b></a>: <em>Bold, daring, or willing to take risks, often in a reckless or disrespectful way.</em></li>
<li id="Audacity"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#audacity"><b>Audacity</b></a>: <em>Excessive boldness or daring, often with disregard for others' opinions or safety.</em></li>
<li id="Auspicious"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#auspicious"><b>Auspicious</b></a>: <em>Indicating a favorable or successful outcome; promising good fortune.</em></li>
<li id="Austere"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#austere"><b>Austere</b></a>: <em>Severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance; simple and unadorned.</em></li>
<li id="Austere"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#austere"><b>Austere</b></a>: <em>Harsh or severe in disposition or nature; lacking in decoration or luxury.</em></li>
<li id="Austere"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#austere"><b>Austere</b></a>: <em>Strict and uncompromising; ascetic or self-disciplined.</em></li>
<li id="Avaricious"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#avaricious"><b>Avaricious</b></a>: <em>Having an insatiable desire for wealth or material gain; greedy.</em></li>

## B

<li id="Banal"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#banal"><b>Banal</b></a>: <em>So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.</em></li>
<li id="Banality"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#banality"><b>Banality</b></a>: <em>The condition or quality of being dull or unoriginal; obvious or trite.</em></li>
<li id="Belie"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#belie"><b>Belie</b></a>: <em>To fail to give a true impression of something; to contradict or misrepresent.</em></li>
<li id="Belligerent"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#belligerent"><b>Belligerent</b></a>: <em>Hostile and aggressive; engaged in conflict or war.</em></li>
<li id="Betray"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#betray"><b>Betray</b></a>: <em>To reveal or disclose something hidden, often by accident or in violation of trust; to be disloyal.</em></li>
<li id="Blatant"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#blatant"><b>Blatant</b></a>: <em>Completely obvious, often offensively so; conspicuously offensive.</em></li>
<li id="Bolster"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#bolster"><b>Bolster</b></a>: <em>To support, strengthen, or reinforce something.</em></li>
<li id="Brazen"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#brazen"><b>Brazen</b></a>: <em>Bold and shameless; audacious in a way that is often disrespectful.</em></li>
<li id="Bucolic"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#bucolic"><b>Bucolic</b></a>: <em>Relating to the countryside or rural life; pastoral.</em></li>
<li id="Bumbling"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#bumbling"><b>Bumbling</b></a>: <em>Characterized by clumsiness or awkwardness, often in a way that causes problems.</em></li>
<li id="Burgeon"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#burgeon"><b>Burgeon</b></a>: <em>To grow or develop rapidly; to flourish or increase quickly.</em></li>

## C

<li id="Calumny"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#calumny"><b>Calumny</b></a>: <em>The making of false and defamatory statements about someone to damage their reputation.</em></li>
<li id="Capricious"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#capricious"><b>Capricious</b></a>: <em>Given to sudden and unaccountable changes in mood or behavior.</em></li>
<li id="Castigate"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#castigate"><b>Castigate</b></a>: <em>To reprimand or criticize severely.</em></li>
<li id="Censure"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#censure"><b>Censure</b></a>: <em>To express severe disapproval of someone or something, typically in a formal statement.</em></li>
<li id="Chastise"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#chastise"><b>Chastise</b></a>: <em>To reprimand or scold severely, often for moral or disciplinary reasons.</em></li>
<li id="Chortle"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#chortle"><b>Chortle</b></a>: <em>To laugh in a gleeful, partly suppressed way.</em></li>
<li id="Circumscribe"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#circumscribe"><b>Circumscribe</b></a>: <em>To restrict or limit something within certain boundaries.</em></li>
<li id="Circumvent"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#circumvent"><b>Circumvent</b></a>: <em>To find a way around an obstacle or limitation, often by clever or deceitful means.</em></li>
<li id="Commensurate"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#commensurate"><b>Commensurate</b></a>: <em>Corresponding in size, degree, or extent; proportionate.</em></li>
<li id="Concede"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#concede"><b>Concede</b></a>: <em>To admit or acknowledge something, often reluctantly; to surrender or yield.</em></li>
<li id="Concede"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#concede"><b>Concede</b></a>: <em>To yield or grant something as a right or privilege.</em></li>
<li id="Concede"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#concede"><b>Concede</b></a>: <em>To accept the truth or validity of something after denying it initially.</em></li>
<li id="Confound"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#confound"><b>Confound</b></a>: <em>To cause confusion or surprise, especially by being unexpected.</em></li>
<li id="Confound"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#confound"><b>Confound</b></a>: <em>To mix up or confuse, often to the point of bewilderment.</em></li>
<li id="Conspicuous"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#conspicuous"><b>Conspicuous</b></a>: <em>Clearly visible or easily noticed; attracting attention.</em></li>
<li id="Constituent"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#constituent"><b>Constituent</b></a>: <em>A component or part of something; a person who authorizes another to act on their behalf.</em></li>
<li id="Constituent"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#constituent"><b>Constituent</b></a>: <em>A member of a group or body of voters who elect representatives.</em></li>
<li id="Construe"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#construe"><b>Construe</b></a>: <em>To interpret or analyze something in a particular way.</em></li>
<li id="Contingent"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#contingent"><b>Contingent</b></a>: <em>Dependent on or subject to chance or certain conditions; likely to occur but not certain.</em></li>
<li id="Contingent"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Contingent"><b>Contingent</b></a>: <em>Dependent on or subject to chance or certain conditions; likely to occur but not certain.</em></li>
<li id="Contrition"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Contrition"><b>Contrition</b></a>: <em>The state of feeling remorseful and repentant for one's wrongdoings.</em></li>
<li id="Contrive"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Contrive"><b>Contrive</b></a>: <em>To plan or create something through clever or ingenious methods, often in a deceptive way.</em></li>
<li id="Copious"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Copious"><b>Copious</b></a>: <em>Abundant in quantity; large in number or amount.</em></li>
<li id="Craven"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Craven"><b>Craven</b></a>: <em>Characterized by cowardice; lacking courage.</em></li>
<li id="Cryptic"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Cryptic"><b>Cryptic</b></a>: <em>Having a hidden or ambiguous meaning; mysterious or obscure.</em></li>
<li id="Culminate"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Culminate"><b>Culminate</b></a>: <em>To reach the highest point, final stage, or climax of something.</em></li>
<li id="Culpability"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Culpability"><b>Culpability</b></a>: <em>The state of being guilty or responsible for something bad or wrong.</em></li>

## D

<li id="Decorous"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Decorous"><b>Decorous</b></a>: <em>Conforming to good taste, proper etiquette, and dignity; polite.</em></li>
<li id="Decorum"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Decorum"><b>Decorum</b></a>: <em>Appropriate behavior, conduct, or manners in a given situation.</em></li>
<li id="Deferential"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Deferential"><b>Deferential</b></a>: <em>Showing respect and esteem for someone or something, often by yielding or submitting to their opinion or wishes.</em></li>
<li id="Deleterious"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Deleterious"><b>Deleterious</b></a>: <em>Having a harmful or damaging effect on something or someone.</em></li>
<li id="Delineate"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Delineate"><b>Delineate</b></a>: <em>To describe or portray something in detail, often with precision.</em></li>
<li id="Demur"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Demur"><b>Demur</b></a>: <em>To raise objections or show reluctance, often in response to a proposal or request.</em></li>
<li id="Denigrate"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Denigrate"><b>Denigrate</b></a>: <em>To criticize or speak ill of someone or something, often unfairly.</em></li>
<li id="Denote"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Denote"><b>Denote</b></a>: <em>To indicate, signify, or be a symbol of something.</em></li>
<li id="Derivative"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Derivative"><b>Derivative</b></a>: <em>Imitative of the work of another, usually lacking originality.</em></li>
<li id="Derive"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Derive"><b>Derive</b></a>: <em>To obtain or receive something from a source or origin.</em></li>
<li id="Derive"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Derive"><b>Derive</b></a>: <em>To trace the origin or source of something.</em></li>
<li id="Dictatorial"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Dictatorial"><b>Dictatorial</b></a>: <em>Having a characteristic of or resembling a dictator; authoritarian and overbearing.</em></li>
<li id="Didactic"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Didactic"><b>Didactic</b></a>: <em>Intended to teach or instruct, often in a moralizing or condescending way.</em></li>
<li id="Diffident"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Diffident"><b>Diffident</b></a>: <em>Lacking self-confidence or assertiveness; shy or reserved.</em></li>
<li id="Dilatory"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Dilatory"><b>Dilatory</b></a>: <em>Tending to delay or procrastinate; slow to take action.</em></li>
<li id="Dilettante"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Dilettante"><b>Dilettante</b></a>: <em>A person who engages in an activity, especially the arts, in a superficial or amateurish way.</em></li>
<li id="Disaffected"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Disaffected"><b>Disaffected</b></a>: <em>Feeling disillusioned or dissatisfied, especially with authority or social structures.</em></li>
<li id="Discrete"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Discrete"><b>Discrete</b></a>: <em>Separate and distinct from one another; individually separate.</em></li>
<li id="Disinterested"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Disinterested"><b>Disinterested</b></a>: <em>Not influenced by personal interest; impartial or unbiased.</em></li>
<li id="Dispassionate"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Dispassionate"><b>Dispassionate</b></a>: <em>Not influenced by strong emotions or personal feelings; objective.</em></li>
<li id="Disseminate"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Disseminate"><b>Disseminate</b></a>: <em>To spread or distribute information, knowledge, or ideas widely.</em></li>
<li id="Dogmatic"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Dogmatic"><b>Dogmatic</b></a>: <em>Stubbornly opinionated, often in a way that is rigid or intolerant of other viewpoints.</em></li>
<li id="Duress"><a href="gre-short-passage.html#Duress"><b>Duress</b></a>: <em>Compulsion by threat or force; the use of threats or coercion to make someone act against their will.</em></li>



</ol>
